elements.content: A three-dimensional metal–organic framework (MOF) {[Eu­(L)­(H2O)2]·DMF} n (1) (H3L = 2′-nitro-3,4′,5-biphenyl tricarboxylic acid) was obtained by hydrothermal methods and was characterized in detail. Compound 1 contains [Eu2] binuclear units, and [Eu2] units are further linked by H3L, forming a three-dimensional structure. Stability tests suggest that compound 1 exhibits high solvent, pH, and thermal stability. Besides, we also explored the influence of pH values in the luminescence emission of 1 which shows that pH has a negligible effect on the luminescence intensity with the range of pH = 3–11. Importantly, luminescent investigations reveal that 1 can selectively detect aspartic acid or histidine among 14 amino acids with good regenerability in water. Meanwhile, the concentration of aspartic acid can be quantitatively determined. We also discuss the mechanism of luminescence quenching and enhancement in detail. Importantly, this Eu-MOF provides a MOF-based luminescence sensor to detect two amino acids for the first time.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional metal-organic framework (MOF) {[Eu(L)(H2O)2]⋅DMF} n  (1) (H3L = 2'-nitro-3,4',5-biphenyl tricarboxylic acid) was obtained by hydrothermal methods and was characterized in detail. Compound 1 contains [Eu2] binuclear units, and [Eu2] units are further linked by H3L, forming a three-dimensional structure. Stability tests suggest that compound 1 exhibits high solvent, pH, and thermal stability. Besides, we also explored the influence of pH values in the luminescence emission of 1 which shows that pH has a negligible effect on the luminescence intensity with the range of pH = 3-11. Importantly, luminescent investigations reveal that 1 can selectively detect aspartic acid or histidine among 14 amino acids with good regenerability in water. Meanwhile, the concentration of aspartic acid can be quantitatively determined. We also discuss the mechanism of luminescence quenching and enhancement in detail. Importantly, this Eu-MOF provides a MOF-based luminescence sensor to detect two amino acids for the first time.

elements.content: A unique, three-dimensional, water-stable lanthanide-organic framework (MOF) (1) was synthesized and structurally characterized. Compound 1 can selectively detect histidine or aspartic acid among 14 amino acids in water. Furthermore, compound 1 can be reused at least five times, and the concentration of aspartic acid can be quantitatively determined. More importantly, 1 represents the first MOF-based luminescent sensor for detecting two amino acids.
elements.clean_text: A unique, three-dimensional, water-stable lanthanide-organic framework (MOF) (1) was synthesized and structurally characterized. Compound 1 can selectively detect histidine or aspartic acid among 14 amino acids in water. Furthermore, compound 1 can be reused at least five times, and the concentration of aspartic acid can be quantitatively determined. More importantly, 1 represents the first MOF-based luminescent sensor for detecting two amino acids.

elements.content: Amino acids, as the essential building blocks for organisms, play an indispensable role in body health, which are the necessities to maintain living activity. On the other hand, the content of amino acids is a significant index to reflect the state of health. For example, people will suffer from many diseases when taking in excessive aspartic acid, including stroke, epilepsy, even more serious diseases. Besides, aspartic acid is the feedstock of many amino acids and is a main excitatory neurotransmitter. In clinical medicine, it also can be employed to treat heart disease, hypertension, hepatopathy, etc. Meanwhile, histidine can be seen as a biomarker to diagnose different diseases such as asthma, and the level of histidine-rich proteins has an influence on advanced liver cirrhosis. Hence, it is so urgent that a suitable solution must be taken to detect aspartic acid and histidine. Lots of ways of detecting amino acids including chromatography, capillary electrophoresis, electrochemistry have been reported so far. However, the methods mentioned above are often time-consuming, have complicated operations and are inconvenient. Comparatively, a luminescence probe possesses obvious advantages such as high selectivity, sensitivity, and recyclability, which is regarded as a fantastic candidate for detecting aspartic acid and histidine.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Amino acids, as the essential building blocks for organisms, play an indispensable role in body health, which are the necessities to maintain living activity. On the other hand, the content of amino acids is a significant index to reflect the state of health. For example, people will suffer from many diseases when taking in excessive aspartic acid, including stroke, epilepsy, even more serious diseases. Besides, aspartic acid is the feedstock of many amino acids and is a main excitatory neurotransmitter. In clinical medicine, it also can be employed to treat heart disease, hypertension, hepatopathy, etc. Meanwhile, histidine can be seen as a biomarker to diagnose different diseases such as asthma, and the level of histidine-rich proteins has an influence on advanced liver cirrhosis. Hence, it is so urgent that a suitable solution must be taken to detect aspartic acid and histidine. Lots of ways of detecting amino acids including chromatography, capillary electrophoresis, electrochemistry have been reported so far. However, the methods mentioned above are often time-consuming, have complicated operations and are inconvenient. Comparatively, a luminescence probe possesses obvious advantages such as high selectivity, sensitivity, and recyclability, which is regarded as a fantastic candidate for detecting aspartic acid and histidine.

elements.content: Additionally, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have drawn more and more attention due to their bright prospects as luminescent probes. In recent years, MOFs as luminescent probes have been applied in following aspects: anions, including Cr2O7 2–/CrO4 2–, CO3 2–, I;– cations, such as Al3+, Fe2+/Fe3+, Cu2+; molecules, explosives, biomolecules; as well as temperature and pH. Although MOF materials have made great progress as luminescent probes, the detection of amino acids remains a challenge. Corresponding reports are rare and only focus on detecting one kind of amino acid. MOF-based luminescent probes which can detect two or more amino acids have not been reported at all.
elements.clean_text: Additionally, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have drawn more and more attention due to their bright prospects as luminescent probes. In recent years, MOFs as luminescent probes have been applied in following aspects: anions, including Cr2O7 2-/CrO4 2-, CO3 2-, I;-  cations, such as Al3+, Fe2+/Fe3+, Cu2+; molecules, explosives, biomolecules; as well as temperature and pH. Although MOF materials have made great progress as luminescent probes, the detection of amino acids remains a challenge. Corresponding reports are rare and only focus on detecting one kind of amino acid. MOF-based luminescent probes which can detect two or more amino acids have not been reported at all.

elements.content: In this manuscript, one unique three-dimensional (3D) Eu-MOF {[Eu­(L)­(H2O)2]­·DMF}n (1) was obtained with H3L ligand and Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O via a solvothermal reaction. Luminescence studies indicate that compound 1 can selectively detect aspartic acid or histidine among 14 kinds of amino acids. In addition, the as-synthesized 1 exhibits excellent recyclability which can be cycled at least five times. To our knowledge, it is the first time that an MOF serves as a luminescent probe to detect two amino acids.
elements.clean_text: In this manuscript, one unique three-dimensional (3D) Eu-MOF {[Eu(L)(H2O)2]⋅DMF}n (1) was obtained with H3L ligand and Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O via a solvothermal reaction. Luminescence studies indicate that compound 1 can selectively detect aspartic acid or histidine among 14 kinds of amino acids. In addition, the as-synthesized 1 exhibits excellent recyclability which can be cycled at least five times. To our knowledge, it is the first time that an MOF serves as a luminescent probe to detect two amino acids.

elements.content:
All of the reagents involved in this article are commercially available and directly applied to the experiments without any operation.

Preparation of {[Eu­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Mixtures of europium nitrate hexahydrate (0.05 mmol, 22 mg) and ligands H3L (0.03 mmol, 10 mg) in 1 mL of deionized water and 2.5 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) were added to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor. Next, the reactor was heated under a temperature of 100 °C for 72 h and dropped until 30 °C with the psyctic rate of 2 °C/h. The block, pale-yellow crystals were largely synthesized. Yield: 76% (based on europium nitrate hexahydrate). Elem anal. Cal: carbon, 36.65; hydrogen, 2.88; nitrogen, 4.75. Found: carbon, 36.71; hydrogen, 2.83; nitrogen, 4.62.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All of the reagents involved in this article are commercially available and directly applied to the experiments without any operation.

Preparation of {[Eu(L)(H2O)2]⋅DMF} n  (1)

Mixtures of europium nitrate hexahydrate (0.05 mmol, 22 mg) and ligands H3L (0.03 mmol, 10 mg) in 1 mL of deionized water and 2.5 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) were added to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor. Next, the reactor was heated under a temperature of 100 °C for 72 h and dropped until 30 °C with the psyctic rate of 2 °C/h. The block, pale-yellow crystals were largely synthesized. Yield: 76% (based on europium nitrate hexahydrate). Elem anal. Cal: carbon, 36.65; hydrogen, 2.88; nitrogen, 4.75. Found: carbon, 36.71; hydrogen, 2.83; nitrogen, 4.62.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of compounds were performed on a Netzsch TG 209 TG-DTA analyzer. The carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen element analyses were obtained from a vario EL CUBE analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction was finished on an Ultima IV diffractometer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was measured using an IRIS Advantage (Thermo). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was carried out on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer. A UV-3600 (SHIMADZU) UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer was used to measure the UV–visible absorption spectra. An F-4500 FL spectrophotometer was used to obtain the fluorescent spectra.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

Thermogravimetric analyses of compounds were performed on a Netzsch TG 209 TG-DTA analyzer. The carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen element analyses were obtained from a vario EL CUBE analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction was finished on an Ultima IV diffractometer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was measured using an IRIS Advantage (Thermo). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was carried out on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer. A UV-3600 (SHIMADZU) UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer was used to measure the UV-visible absorption spectra. An F-4500 FL spectrophotometer was used to obtain the fluorescent spectra.

elements.content: A suitable crystal was selected to obtain crystallography data on a SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer in a N2 gas stream under the radiation of graphite-monochromatic Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure of compound 1 was determined by direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 with SHELXS and SHELXL programs. Many efforts were in vain to handle the highly disordered solvents, so we used PLATON/SQUEEZE to remove the free solvents. All the atoms were refined anisotropically (except H atoms). And the ultimate molecular formulas of compound were combined with the result of TGA and element analysis. CCDC 1882957.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

A suitable crystal was selected to obtain crystallography data on a SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer in a N2 gas stream under the radiation of graphite-monochromatic Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure of compound 1 was determined by direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 with SHELXS and SHELXL programs. Many efforts were in vain to handle the highly disordered solvents, so we used PLATON/SQUEEZE to remove the free solvents. All the atoms were refined anisotropically (except H atoms). And the ultimate molecular formulas of compound were combined with the result of TGA and element analysis. CCDC 1882957.

elements.content:
The space group of compound 1 is C2/c, and this Eu-MOF crystallizes in the monoclinic system ().

The asymmetric unit contains a Eu3+ ion, a H3L, two coordinated H2O, and one dissociative DMF. Each Eu3+ ion in compound 1 is coordinated with nine O atoms, which belong to two H2O and four H3L ligands (Figure S1). The lengths of Eu–OCOO‑ bond fall into the range 2.366–2.683 Å, while Eu–Owater bond distances are 2.458 and 2.438 Å. Those bond lengths are in accord with the reported ones. Additionally, two Eu3+ cations are linked with oxygen atoms from four carboxyl of H3L, forming [Eu2] binuclear unit (a). Next, each [Eu2] unit is connected by six H3L, while every H3L links three [Eu2] (Figure S2), forming a 3D framework. Along the c-axis, there is a one-dimensional channel with a diameter of 8.5 Å and 37.1% of potential pore volume approximately, which is calculated by the PLATON program (b,c). Along the a-axis, three kinds of channels exist with rectangle, rhombus, and quadrangle, with a rectangle channel of 4.81 Å × 5.11 Å for the b-axis (Figure S3). Accordingly, compound 1 will be predigested as a 3,6-linked net with the point symbol of {4^2;6}­2­{4^4;6^2;­8^7;10^2} belonging to flu-3 topology type (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Analysis

The space group of compound 1 is C2/c, and this Eu-MOF crystallizes in the monoclinic system ().

The asymmetric unit contains a Eu3+ ion, a H3L, two coordinated H2O, and one dissociative DMF. Each Eu3+ ion in compound 1 is coordinated with nine O atoms, which belong to two H2O and four H3L ligands (Figure S1). The lengths of Eu-OCOO- bond fall into the range 2.366-2.683 Å, while Eu-Owater bond distances are 2.458 and 2.438 Å. Those bond lengths are in accord with the reported ones. Additionally, two Eu3+ cations are linked with oxygen atoms from four carboxyl of H3L, forming [Eu2] binuclear unit (a). Next, each [Eu2] unit is connected by six H3L, while every H3L links three [Eu2] (Figure S2), forming a 3D framework. Along the c-axis, there is a one-dimensional channel with a diameter of 8.5 Å and 37.1% of potential pore volume approximately, which is calculated by the PLATON program (b,c). Along the a-axis, three kinds of channels exist with rectangle, rhombus, and quadrangle, with a rectangle channel of 4.81 Å × 5.11 Å for the b-axis (Figure S3). Accordingly, compound 1 will be predigested as a 3,6-linked net with the point symbol of {4^2;6}2{4^4;6^2;8^7;10^2} belonging to flu-3 topology type (d).

elements.content: PXRD results show that all the experimental PXRD peaks can find the corresponding peaks in the theoretical patterns, suggesting good phase purity of 1 (Figure S4). Besides, 30 mg of the samples was put into 10 mL of organic solvents such as DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, CH3OH, C2H5OH, etc. at room temperature for 6 h, and then the samples were recollected by centrifugation and air-drying before PXRD measurement. The patterns conform with the theoretical ones, which suggests 1 has good solvent stability (Figure S5). Furthermore, to explore the pH stability of the obtained compound, 1 was put into deionized water solutions with different pH values for 6 h. The experiment patterns still conform to the patterns fitted by crystal data, implying that the framework of compound 1 remains intact with pH values ranging from 2 to 12 (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetry (TG) and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

PXRD results show that all the experimental PXRD peaks can find the corresponding peaks in the theoretical patterns, suggesting good phase purity of 1 (Figure S4). Besides, 30 mg of the samples was put into 10 mL of organic solvents such as DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, CH3OH, C2H5OH, etc. at room temperature for 6 h, and then the samples were recollected by centrifugation and air-drying before PXRD measurement. The patterns conform with the theoretical ones, which suggests 1 has good solvent stability (Figure S5). Furthermore, to explore the pH stability of the obtained compound, 1 was put into deionized water solutions with different pH values for 6 h. The experiment patterns still conform to the patterns fitted by crystal data, implying that the framework of compound 1 remains intact with pH values ranging from 2 to 12 (Figure S6).

elements.content: To explore the thermal stability of complex 1, thermogravimetric tests were conducted under N2 atmosphere. The TG curve of as-synthesized 1 exhibted that a weight loss of 11.71% occurred within 40–160 °C, which results from the removal of free DMF solvent in the pore (theoretical value: 12.24%). The framework of 1 is still stable at 300 °C, suggesting that complex 1 has good thermal stability (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: To explore the thermal stability of complex 1, thermogravimetric tests were conducted under N2 atmosphere. The TG curve of as-synthesized 1 exhibted that a weight loss of 11.71% occurred within 40-160 °C, which results from the removal of free DMF solvent in the pore (theoretical value: 12.24%). The framework of 1 is still stable at 300 °C, suggesting that complex 1 has good thermal stability (Figure S7).

elements.content: Under the exciting wavelength at 260 nm, luminescent spectra of compound 1 and H3L ligand in water were measured, and relevant results were recorded in Figure S9. For compound 1, there are three main peaks at 420, 485, and 529 nm, which are in accordance with the characteristic peaks of H3L ligand, suggesting the luminescence of 1 results from the π* → π or π* → n transitions of H3L.
elements.clean_text: Under the exciting wavelength at 260 nm, luminescent spectra of compound 1 and H3L ligand in water were measured, and relevant results were recorded in Figure S9. For compound 1, there are three main peaks at 420, 485, and 529 nm, which are in accordance with the characteristic peaks of H3L ligand, suggesting the luminescence of 1 results from the π* → π or π* → n transitions of H3L.

elements.content: To study the effect of pH, we tested the luminescence intensity of compound 1 with different pH values, which show that pH has a negligible effect on the luminescent emission from pH = 3–11 (). Besides, time is an important parameter to measure the stability of MOF luminescent probes. So we monitored luminescence intensity of compound 1 within 90 min, indicating that the emission almost does not change with increasing time (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text: To study the effect of pH, we tested the luminescence intensity of compound 1 with different pH values, which show that pH has a negligible effect on the luminescent emission from pH = 3-11 (). Besides, time is an important parameter to measure the stability of MOF luminescent probes. So we monitored luminescence intensity of compound 1 within 90 min, indicating that the emission almost does not change with increasing time (Figure S10).

elements.content: Emission intensity of 1 in deionized water solution with different pH values (bar diagrams represent the luminescence intensity at a wavelength of 420 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  Emission intensity of 1 in deionized water solution with different pH values (bar diagrams represent the luminescence intensity at a wavelength of 420 nm).

elements.content: Considering good luminescent properties and stabilities of compound 1, we wanted to know whether it can be used for sensing common amino acids in water. To investigate the influence of different amino acids in luminescent emission of 1, several amino acids, including l-histidine (His), l-leucine (Leu), l-valine (Val), l-cysteine (Cys), l-glycine (Gly), l-phenylalanine (Phe), l-tyrosine (Tyr), l-asparaginate (Asn), l-proline (Pro), l-isoleucine (Ile), l-methionine (Met), l-glutamine (Gln), l-threonine (Thr), and l-aspartic acid (Asp), were investigated. In a typical experiment, 2.5 mg of the as-synthesized compound was ground and put into 2.8 mL of deionized water solutions of different amino acids. After ultrasonic dispersion for 20 min, suspension solutions were formed. The obtained suspensions were monitored by a fluorospectro photometer, and the peak at 420 nm is shown in . Interestingly, most of the amino acids have a negligible influence on the luminescence. Aspartic acid (Asp) shows a strong quenching effect, while histidine (His) exhibits enhanced luminescence on the emission of compound 1, indicating that 1 has the potential to serve as a luminescent sensor to detect aspartic acid or histidine. Besides, we explore the luminescent emission after adding aspartic acid or histidine with increasing time. As shown in Figure S11, it is about 30 s that the luminescence intensity can become stable and maintain a constant value with negligible loss. Furthermore, the relationship of luminescent intensity and the concentration of aspartic acid can be fitted into I = −32734­[Asp] + 495.9 (I represents the luminescent intensity of 1; [Asp] is the concentration of aspartic acid, Figure S12). As a result, compound 1 not only can selectively detect aspartic acid, but also can determine the concentration of aspartic acid quantitatively. As far as we know, luminescent probes based on MOFs to detect two amino acids have not been introduced (Table S1).
elements.clean_text: Considering good luminescent properties and stabilities of compound 1, we wanted to know whether it can be used for sensing common amino acids in water. To investigate the influence of different amino acids in luminescent emission of 1, several amino acids, including l-histidine (His), l-leucine (Leu), l-valine (Val), l-cysteine (Cys), l-glycine (Gly), l-phenylalanine (Phe), l-tyrosine (Tyr), l-asparaginate (Asn), l-proline (Pro), l-isoleucine (Ile), l-methionine (Met), l-glutamine (Gln), l-threonine (Thr), and l-aspartic acid (Asp), were investigated. In a typical experiment, 2.5 mg of the as-synthesized compound was ground and put into 2.8 mL of deionized water solutions of different amino acids. After ultrasonic dispersion for 20 min, suspension solutions were formed. The obtained suspensions were monitored by a fluorospectro photometer, and the peak at 420 nm is shown in . Interestingly, most of the amino acids have a negligible influence on the luminescence. Aspartic acid (Asp) shows a strong quenching effect, while histidine (His) exhibits enhanced luminescence on the emission of compound 1, indicating that 1 has the potential to serve as a luminescent sensor to detect aspartic acid or histidine. Besides, we explore the luminescent emission after adding aspartic acid or histidine with increasing time. As shown in Figure S11, it is about 30 s that the luminescence intensity can become stable and maintain a constant value with negligible loss. Furthermore, the relationship of luminescent intensity and the concentration of aspartic acid can be fitted into I = -32734[Asp] + 495.9 (I represents the luminescent intensity of 1; [Asp] is the concentration of aspartic acid, Figure S12). As a result, compound 1 not only can selectively detect aspartic acid, but also can determine the concentration of aspartic acid quantitatively. As far as we know, luminescent probes based on MOFs to detect two amino acids have not been introduced (Table S1).

elements.content: Luminescence intensity of complex 1 after immersing in aqueous solution of 14 amino acids (λ = 420 nm).
elements.clean_text: 3  Luminescence intensity of complex 1 after immersing in aqueous solution of 14 amino acids (λ = 420 nm).

elements.content: Besides, the sensitivity of 1 as a luminescent sensor of aspartic acid and histidine was investigated. A total of 2.5 mg of samples was ground and dispersed in a series of aspartic acid deionized water solution with different concentrations. The luminescence intensity of complex 1 slowly decreases with the concentration of aspartic acid increasing. Finally, the luminescent intensity almost completely quenches as the concentration of aspartic acid increases to 2.88 × 10–3 M (). To further study the quenching effect of aspartic acid, a plot of I 0/I and [Asp] was established, which obeys I 0/I = 0.949 + K sv[Asp] (I 0 is the original intensity of 1, I is the luminescence intensity after adding aspartic acid, K sv is quenching rate constant, [Asp] represents the concentration of aspartic acid) ().The value of K sv is 1.09 × 103 mol L–1, which reveals the good quenching efficiency of aspartic acid for compound 1.
elements.clean_text: Besides, the sensitivity of 1 as a luminescent sensor of aspartic acid and histidine was investigated. A total of 2.5 mg of samples was ground and dispersed in a series of aspartic acid deionized water solution with different concentrations. The luminescence intensity of complex 1 slowly decreases with the concentration of aspartic acid increasing. Finally, the luminescent intensity almost completely quenches as the concentration of aspartic acid increases to 2.88 × 10-3 M (). To further study the quenching effect of aspartic acid, a plot of I 0/I and [Asp] was established, which obeys I 0/I = 0.949 + K sv[Asp] (I 0 is the original intensity of 1, I is the luminescence intensity after adding aspartic acid, K sv is quenching rate constant, [Asp] represents the concentration of aspartic acid) ().The value of K sv is 1.09 × 103 mol L-1, which reveals the good quenching efficiency of aspartic acid for compound 1.

elements.content: Liquid luminescent spectra of compound 1 after adding different concentrations of aspartic acid in water and the luminescence intensity vs aspartic acid concentration plot (λ = 420 nm).
elements.clean_text: 4  Liquid luminescent spectra of compound 1 after adding different concentrations of aspartic acid in water and the luminescence intensity vs aspartic acid concentration plot (λ = 420 nm).

elements.content: Meanwhile, the emission intensity of compound 1 is enhanced when the concentration of histidine increases and the enhanced intensity can be observed even when 1 was dispersed in a histidine solution of 10–4 M, indicating the detection limit of this Eu-MOF to sense histidine can reach 10–4 M (). Actually, there is only one MOF to detect histidine which was reported by Moorthy, and histidine can quench the luminescence of Zn-MOF. In general, this is the first time that MOFs as luminescent probes can detect histidine by enhanced luminescence. The relationship between luminescent intensity and histidine concentration was also explored, which cannot be fitted by the Stern–Volmer equation, revealing there exists both dynamic and static processes.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the emission intensity of compound 1 is enhanced when the concentration of histidine increases and the enhanced intensity can be observed even when 1 was dispersed in a histidine solution of 10-4 M, indicating the detection limit of this Eu-MOF to sense histidine can reach 10-4 M (). Actually, there is only one MOF to detect histidine which was reported by Moorthy, and histidine can quench the luminescence of Zn-MOF. In general, this is the first time that MOFs as luminescent probes can detect histidine by enhanced luminescence. The relationship between luminescent intensity and histidine concentration was also explored, which cannot be fitted by the Stern-Volmer equation, revealing there exists both dynamic and static processes.

elements.content: Liquid luminescent spectra of compound 1 after immersing in histidine aqueous solutions with different concentrations (λ = 420 nm).
elements.clean_text: 5  Liquid luminescent spectra of compound 1 after immersing in histidine aqueous solutions with different concentrations (λ = 420 nm).

elements.content: The reproducibility of luminescence probes is a significant parameter in order to apply to practice well. Therefore, the recyclability of compound 1 as an aspartic acid probe was investigated. As shown in and Figure S14, the PXRD patterns and luminescent intensity of recycled 1 are in accordance with the initial ones. After recycling five times, those results still conform with the pristine ones, suggesting that compound 1 possesses regenerability. As a histidine sensor, we also studied the recycling performance of complex 1, and the results are shown in Figures S13–S14. The PXRD patterns still conform with the initial patterns, and the luminescent intensity of recycled 1 exhibits negligible loss even after five times. Additionally, inductively coupled plasma spectrometer (ICP) of compound 1 was measured to analyze the leaching of Eu3+, and the leakage percentages of Eu3+ are negligible, revealing that complex 1 is able to serve as a renewable luminescence probe for aspartic acid and histidine (Table S2).
elements.clean_text: The reproducibility of luminescence probes is a significant parameter in order to apply to practice well. Therefore, the recyclability of compound 1 as an aspartic acid probe was investigated. As shown in  and Figure S14, the PXRD patterns and luminescent intensity of recycled 1 are in accordance with the initial ones. After recycling five times, those results still conform with the pristine ones, suggesting that compound 1 possesses regenerability. As a histidine sensor, we also studied the recycling performance of complex 1, and the results are shown in Figures S13-S14. The PXRD patterns still conform with the initial patterns, and the luminescent intensity of recycled 1 exhibits negligible loss even after five times. Additionally, inductively coupled plasma spectrometer (ICP) of compound 1 was measured to analyze the leaching of Eu3+, and the leakage percentages of Eu3+ are negligible, revealing that complex 1 is able to serve as a renewable luminescence probe for aspartic acid and histidine (Table S2).

elements.content: Luminescent intensity of compound 1 for aspartic acid after five recycles (λ = 420 nm).
elements.clean_text: 6  Luminescent intensity of compound 1 for aspartic acid after five recycles (λ = 420 nm).

elements.content: In the next step, the probable mechanism was put forward. First, the consistent PXRD patterns confirm that the framework remains stable after detecting amino acids, indicating the luminescent quenching or enhancement does not result from the framework collapse (Figure S14). Second, luminescent intensity and the concentration of aspartic acid is able to fit with the Stern–Volmer equation, suggesting the quenching process of compound 1 may result from a dynamic process. Namely, the collision interaction between aspartic acid and framework of compound 1 leads to the energy loss, which results in luminescence quenching.
elements.clean_text: In the next step, the probable mechanism was put forward. First, the consistent PXRD patterns confirm that the framework remains stable after detecting amino acids, indicating the luminescent quenching or enhancement does not result from the framework collapse (Figure S14). Second, luminescent intensity and the concentration of aspartic acid is able to fit with the Stern-Volmer equation, suggesting the quenching process of compound 1 may result from a dynamic process. Namely, the collision interaction between aspartic acid and framework of compound 1 leads to the energy loss, which results in luminescence quenching.

elements.content: Third, to explain the mechanism of luminescent enhancement, we explored the energy transformation between histidine and H3L ligand. The process of intersystem crossing can become efficient when the energy gap (ΔE) between the singlet-state (S1) and triplet-state (T1) of ligand is more than 5000 cm–1 given the experiential rule of Reinhold. The energy value of S1 is calculated from the UV–vis spectra of ligand. Because the lower excited state of Gd3+ is very high, it cannot absorb the energy from ligands. Therefore, the energy of the T1 state of ligand can be obtained from the phosphorescence spectrum of isostructural Gd complex. Meanwhile, the energy of T1 is required to be 1700 cm–1 larger than the energy of 5D0 of Eu3+ (17 500 cm–1) aiming to sensitize the Eu3+ centers.
elements.clean_text: Third, to explain the mechanism of luminescent enhancement, we explored the energy transformation between histidine and H3L ligand. The process of intersystem crossing can become efficient when the energy gap (ΔE) between the singlet-state (S1) and triplet-state (T1) of ligand is more than 5000 cm-1 given the experiential rule of Reinhold. The energy value of S1 is calculated from the UV-vis spectra of ligand. Because the lower excited state of Gd3+ is very high, it cannot absorb the energy from ligands. Therefore, the energy of the T1 state of ligand can be obtained from the phosphorescence spectrum of isostructural Gd complex. Meanwhile, the energy of T1 is required to be 1700 cm-1 larger than the energy of 5D0 of Eu3+ (17500 cm-1) aiming to sensitize the Eu3+ centers.

elements.content: On the basis of the analysis above, the UV–vis spectra of H3L were obtained, which are exhibited in Figure S15, and the energy level of S1 can be calculated as 38 461 cm–1. Meanwhile, we synthesized an isostructural crystal with a Gd metal center denoted as compound 2, and the phosphorescence spectrum of compound 2 was measured under the temperature of 77 K (Figure S16). There is a clear peak at about 480 nm, indicating the corresponding energy of T1 is 20833 cm–1. The ΔE between S1 and T1 is 17 628 cm–1, which is more than 5000 cm–1, revealing that the process of intersystem crossing of compound 1 is efficient. The energy gap within Eu3+ and T1 of H3L is 3333 cm–1, which is larger than 1700 cm–1, revealing that Eu metal centers can be sensitized and will accept a little energy from ligand. The weak emission peak at the wavelength of 616 nm in the spectra of compound 1 further supports our assumption.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the analysis above, the UV-vis spectra of H3L were obtained, which are exhibited in Figure S15, and the energy level of S1 can be calculated as 38461 cm-1. Meanwhile, we synthesized an isostructural crystal with a Gd metal center denoted as compound 2, and the phosphorescence spectrum of compound 2 was measured under the temperature of 77 K (Figure S16). There is a clear peak at about 480 nm, indicating the corresponding energy of T1 is 20833 cm-1. The ΔE between S1 and T1 is 17628 cm-1, which is more than 5000 cm-1, revealing that the process of intersystem crossing of compound 1 is efficient. The energy gap within Eu3+ and T1 of H3L is 3333 cm-1, which is larger than 1700 cm-1, revealing that Eu metal centers can be sensitized and will accept a little energy from ligand. The weak emission peak at the wavelength of 616 nm in the spectra of compound 1 further supports our assumption.

elements.content: Furthermore, the spectra of UV–vis of l-histidine were tested (Figure S17). The consequences reveal that l-histidine (His) will absorb the energy when the exciting wavelength is 260 nm. Accordingly, the S1 energy level of His is 44 823 cm–1 which is higher than that of H3L (38461 cm–1). So the energy will transfer to H3L ligand from His, leading to the luminescence enhancement ().
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the spectra of UV-vis of l-histidine were tested (Figure S17). The consequences reveal that l-histidine (His) will absorb the energy when the exciting wavelength is 260 nm. Accordingly, the S1 energy level of His is 44823 cm-1 which is higher than that of H3L (38461 cm-1). So the energy will transfer to H3L ligand from His, leading to the luminescence enhancement ().

elements.content: Simplified schematic diagram of the energy transfer for the luminescence emission.
elements.clean_text: 7  Simplified schematic diagram of the energy transfer for the luminescence emission.

elements.content: In summary, a unique lanthanide framework was synthesized and characterized in detail. This material exhibits high solvent, pH, and thermal stability. The luminescent results imply that 1 has ability to detect aspartic acid or histidine among 14 amino acids in water, and the concentration of aspartic acid can be quantitatively determined. In addition, compound 1 can be reused at a minimum of five times, indicating the excellent recyclability of this luminescent sensor. Importantly, 1 is the first instance of a luminescent probe based on MOFs to detect two amino acids.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a unique lanthanide framework was synthesized and characterized in detail. This material exhibits high solvent, pH, and thermal stability. The luminescent results imply that 1 has ability to detect aspartic acid or histidine among 14 amino acids in water, and the concentration of aspartic acid can be quantitatively determined. In addition, compound 1 can be reused at a minimum of five times, indicating the excellent recyclability of this luminescent sensor. Importantly, 1 is the first instance of a luminescent probe based on MOFs to detect two amino acids.

cln_elements.content:
All of the reagents involved in this article are commercially available and directly applied to the experiments without any operation.

Preparation of {[Eu­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Mixtures of europium nitrate hexahydrate (0.05 mmol, 22 mg) and ligands H3L (0.03 mmol, 10 mg) in 1 mL of deionized water and 2.5 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) were added to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor. Next, the reactor was heated under a temperature of 100 °C for 72 h and dropped until 30 °C with the psyctic rate of 2 °C/h. The block, pale-yellow crystals were largely synthesized. Yield: 76% (based on europium nitrate hexahydrate). Elem anal. Cal: carbon, 36.65; hydrogen, 2.88; nitrogen, 4.75. Found: carbon, 36.71; hydrogen, 2.83; nitrogen, 4.62.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All of the reagents involved in this article are commercially available and directly applied to the experiments without any operation.

Preparation of {[Eu(L)(H2O)2]⋅DMF} n  (1)

Mixtures of europium nitrate hexahydrate (0.05 mmol, 22 mg) and ligands H3L (0.03 mmol, 10 mg) in 1 mL of deionized water and 2.5 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) were added to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor. Next, the reactor was heated under a temperature of 100 °C for 72 h and dropped until 30 °C with the psyctic rate of 2 °C/h. The block, pale-yellow crystals were largely synthesized. Yield: 76% (based on europium nitrate hexahydrate). Elem anal. Cal: carbon, 36.65; hydrogen, 2.88; nitrogen, 4.75. Found: carbon, 36.71; hydrogen, 2.83; nitrogen, 4.62.


cln_elements.content: To explore the thermal stability of complex 1, thermogravimetric tests were conducted under N2 atmosphere. The TG curve of as-synthesized 1 exhibted that a weight loss of 11.71% occurred within 40–160 °C, which results from the removal of free DMF solvent in the pore (theoretical value: 12.24%). The framework of 1 is still stable at 300 °C, suggesting that complex 1 has good thermal stability (Figure S7).

The TG curve of as-synthesized 1 exhibted that a weight loss of 11.71% occurred within 40-160 °C, which results from the removal of free DMF solvent in the pore (theoretical value: 12.24%). The framework of 1 is still stable at 300 °C, suggesting that complex 1 has good thermal stability (Figure S7).

metadata.title:
Stable Lanthanide–Organic Framework as a Luminescent
Probe To Detect Both Histidine and Aspartic Acid in Water
